content: Actually I found it easier than matching brackets :O

The Brackets suite summary in one simple diagram: http://imgur.com/a/27wV9
- CoC: no link (if you've got access, you know how to find it anyway)
- extreme (by Plopx) https://www.codingame.com/training/community/brackets,-extreme-edition. 
- Extended https://www.codingame.com/contributions/view/495f15542e1c3be6a1b4f01520bb122b2d5
- [You are here] Enhanced https://www.codingame.com/contributions/view/4739a66cbd66670413112443a1f1d83ab42
- Ultimate https://www.codingame.com/contributions/view/493e4e48e74e8227c35f0375332bf01629f
- Impossible https://www.codingame.com/contributions/view/4751d4a738728edda725fb18ec86163cf76

Following demonstration by nicola of easier algorithm, and my failure to find a counterexample for it, I'll be inserting  an intermediate difficulty one between this one and the hard one.

So I'm renaming this one 'Enhanced', so we can have the following difficulty ordering:

Extreme (by Plopx) < Extended < Enhanced < Ultimate < whatever (currently Extremely Ultimate, but who knows we can find something better).

Upon the grouping of community puzzles with the classic practice puzzles, this puzzle, having no original classification of difficulty, was grouped into the Hard puzzles. I have now changed the difficulty to Medium to make it at least on par with the Ultimate version (which somebody has set the difficulty as Medium and I have just approved).

If the difficulty levels do not seem appropriate please do adjust them :)

For reference, the Extreme version (also having no difficulty classified before) is currently grouped into the Easy puzzles.
Come to think of it, I'd need an actual explanation here. The "fast" algorithm nicola Kyran and I implemented works just fine on the simple bracket matching. What have *you* been doing?

I alrready gave some elements in other kata's comments, so I will be more precise here.
I made a variation of a widespread stack-based bracket matching algorithm (as I said, it differs by a test and a push)
Using a stack allows me to use as many brackets as I want and this time, I don't focus on opening and closing brackets, but just on the type of this brackets: that's why I said it is simpler.

I think the current classification of most puzzles is completely preposterous.

FWIW, Stock Exchange Losses and Conway Sequence are in Medium, and IMHO every single bracket-themed puzzle is harder than those (including Plopx's original).

I don't particularly care where my problems get classified. If they're the only ones standing out with 10 people who solved them in the easy list, someont might someday notice that that's a much more reasonable classification than user opinions.

Thanks. OK, I'll check that out.

I'm not sure how to define difficulty, but Plopx's puzzle shows a high success rate (2243 / 2602 or 86%).
